document.masterDocTitle: Seven new species of the cicada genus Guyalna Boulard & Martinelli, 1996 (Hemiptera: Cicadidae: Fidicinini) with a re-description of the type species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Seven new species of the cicada genus Guyalna Boulard & Martinelli, 1996 (Hemiptera: Cicadidae: Fidicinini) with a re-description of the type species

subSubSection.paragraph: Type material . Lectotype ♂ ( Fig. 1 ) and paralectotype ♀, here designated. The specimens are deposited in MLP under the numbers 1658/1 and 1658/2, respectively. Lectotype labels: “ Fidicina bonaerensis Berg , handwr; and Dorisia bonaerensis (Berg) , handwr.” and “typus”. Paralectotype label: “typus”.

Diagnosis . The species can be distinguished from all other species of
Guyalna
by the color of the head, pronotum and mesonotum and the yellowish wing veins, the uncus with spines and the median uncus lobe with a median suture and narrow lateral margins. This species has a similar morphology to
G. flavipronotum Sanborn, 2007
( Sanborn 2016a ) and
G. atalapae Boulard & Martinelli, 2011
due the wing vein coloration, the infuscation around the second and third transverse veins of fore wings and the shape of the timbal cover.
G. bonaerensis
can be distinguished from the first by the color of mesonotum that is castaneous in
G. flavipronotum
and yellow in
G. bonaerensis
and from the second by the lateral sigillae stained in black anteriorly, the black band extending laterally reaching the scutellum and the distal portion of the wings not bronzed.

Color . Head, pronotum and mesonotum yellow. Abdomen brown in dorsal view and tawny in ventral view. Basal cell, base of clavus and jugum of fore wings yellowish, Basal area of hind wings yellowish. Legs tawny proximally, becoming dark distally.

Description. Head ( Fig. 4 ) including eyes, broader than pronotum (except pronotal collar) and mesonotum. Vertex with transverse black band departing from each eye reaching the anterior margin of postclypeus and supraantennal plates in dorsal view. Elliptical eyes projecting laterally beyond anterior angles of pronotum, internal margin of eyes tangent to imaginary line continued from lateral fissure of pronotum. Area behind eyes almost equal to smaller diameter of eyes in dorsal view. Lateral ocelli widely separated, distance between them equivalent to distance between each lateral ocellus and eye. Lateral ocelli laterally projected, higher than median ocellus in frontal view. Postclypeus (Fig. 2) with seventeen transverse ridges, oval in ventral view and globose in lateral view, apex prominent in dorsal view relative to supra-antennal plates. Central sulcus shallow and slender. Anteclypeus black with tawny carina, apex of bifurcation in half-moon form black. Lorum black with setae. Rostrum with tawny mentum and labium. Labium short, reaching the posterior margin of basisternum 3, black at apex.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–3.
Guyalna bonaerensis
. 1. Lectotype male (MLP) in dorsal view; 2. Postclypeus in ventral view; 3. Timbal cover in lateral view. Scales bar 1: 1 cm; 2, 3: 2 mm. Figure 1 courtesy of Dr. Ana M. Marino de Remes Lenicov (MLP).

FIGURES 4–10.
Guyalna bonaerensis
, male. 4. Head and thorax in dorsal view; 5. Basisternum 3 in ventral view; 6. Right operculum in ventral view; 7. Sternite VII in ventral view; 8. Pygofer in ventrolateral view; 9. Theca in ventral view; 10. Theca in lateral left view. Scales bar 4–8: 1 mm; 9, 10: 0.5 mm.

FIGURES 11–13.
Guyalna bonaerensis
, female. 11. Left operculum in ventral view; 12. Sternite VII in ventral view; 13. Ovipositor in ventral view. Scales bar 11, 12: 1 mm; 3: 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution. Brazil ( Pará , Mato Grosso , Rio Grande do Sul *),
Paraguay
, Argentina , Uruguay .
